FeedItems.Title: Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
co-authored by Scott Bommarito
At Microsoft, using the latest and secure encryption techniques is very important to us to ensure the security and privacy of our customers. TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1,...

FeedItems.Title: Deprecating packages on nuget.org
FeedItems.Summary: We are excited to announce that nuget.org now supports package deprecation. This has been a long standing ask that will help the ecosystem use supported packages. As a package publisher on nuget.org,...

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[CPVM] Drive the definition for the customer interview questions" (#9836) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
A set of interviews will be conducted to collect customer feedback for CPVM. 

The customer outreach data will need to provide the information necessary to answer to the below questions: 
1.	Is CPVM is a feature that the users need?
2.	What is the Priority of tools the users value most in context of CPVM?
3.	Is there any feedback for the desired Version Override experience? 
4.	What are the adoption blockers (if any)?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[CPVM] Customer outreach" (#9835) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Epic that contains the customer outreach related tasks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Reduce resource contention at solution load time cause by blocking a threadpool thread with BlockingCollection.Take" (#9822) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
At solution load time, we listen for nominations and we try to batch as many of them into one restore operation. 

We either wait for all projects to get nominated or for 20s.

Trick is we are waiting by blocking a threadpool thread: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/4a02c08cb2cfb87c77f0d378e361052944b8f3aa/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.SolutionRestoreManager/SolutionRestoreWorker.cs#L491.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Visual Studio hangs at "Clear All NuGet cache(s)" (#9831) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/816613/visual-studio-hangs-at-clear-all-nuget-caches.html)._ --- Reproduction steps: Clear cache through the Options window --> NuGet Package Manager --> General --> Clear All NuGet Cache(s) What happens: Visual Studio clears cache but then hangs with high CPU usage and no disk activity Expected: Visual Studio clears cache in a separate thread (so that UI is not blocked), shows the progress and does not use high CPU after it finishes. --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 11/13/2019, 02:09 AM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Nikolche Kolev [MSFT] on 11/13/2019, 05:56 PM:

Thank you filing this issue.

Is this something that you can reliably reproduce?

Was the UI completely frozen? Were you able to clean anywhere?

The deletion itself doesn’t block on the UI thread, but it’s possible something else is happening because the global packages folder is being cleared (which is where the assemblies are being consumed for intellisense).

#### Feedback Bot on 11/26/2019, 07:05 PM: We will close this report in 7 days because we don’t have enough information to investigate further. To keep the problem open, please provide the requested details. #### brian.flauto on 7/22/2020, 10:08 AM:

I have found a work-around if anyone is interested. In my case, this was only happening when i had the "Output" window opened and docked in a split view, separate from my "Error List". Once I moved the "Output" window back into my tabbed group of windows, the problem went away.

I noticed something would happen when i clicked "Clear all NuGet Caches". My "Error List" window would come into focus and my "Output" window would attempt to display the package manager ouput. I suspect something between these two UI events are clashing.

#### Feedback Bot on 7/22/2020, 11:33 AM:

Thank you for sharing your feedback! Our teams prioritize action on product issues with broad customer impact. See details at: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/report-a-problem?view=vs-2019#faq. In case you need answers to common questions or need assisted support, be sure to use https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/support/. We’ll keep you posted on any updates to this feedback.

--- ### Original Solutions #### Feedback Bot solved on 12/4/2019, 06:05 PM, 0 votes: We are unable to investigate this issue further without the additional information requested. #### Jason Anderson on 1/9/2020, 10:57 AM:

Myself along with other co-workers are experiencing this same exact issue. We've updated a nuget package (from a private feed) and from another project tried to update latest reference of the newly published package. Upon updating get an error "Package 'PackageName x.x.x.x is not found in the following primary source(s): http...". This typically means from past experience that the nuget cache needs to be cleared so it can find it. When we hit "Clear All NuGet Cache(s)" under Options > Nuget Package Manager > General Visual Studio locks up. I hope this is enough information to re-open this issue.

#### Juha Lehtinen on 2/28/2020, 11:42 PM:

Same issue in Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2019 Version 16.4.5.

Literally what I did: Open Visual Studio => Continue without code => Tools => Nuget Package Manager => Clear All NuGet Cache(s).

The cache is cleared and Visual Studio blocks with high CPU usage and relatively high GPU usage. No way out than killing it.

Happens every time if Output view is open before clearing the cache.

Does not happen if Output view is not open before clearing the cache.

Events.RelatedBody: In the current behavior when using floating version we are not displaying the correct installed version and we are getting this version from the PackageReference instead of the assets file.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
